title: Linear map
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, and more specifically in <a href="linear%20algebra">linear algebra</a>, a linear map (also called a linear mapping, linear transformation, vector space homomorphism, or in some contexts linear function) is a <a href="Map%20%28mathematics%29">mapping</a> formula_1 between two <a href="vector%20space">vector space</a>s that preserves the operations of <a href="vector%20addition">vector addition</a> and <a href="scalar%20multiplication">scalar multiplication</a>. The same names and the same definition are also used for the more general case of <a href="module%20%28mathematics%29">modules</a> over a <a href="ring%20%28mathematics%29">ring</a>; see <a href="Module%20homomorphism">Module homomorphism</a>.
If a linear map is a <a href="bijection">bijection</a> then it is called a . In the case where formula_2, a linear map is called a (linear) "<a href="endomorphism">endomorphism</a>". Sometimes the term linear operator refers to this case, but the term "linear operator" can have different meanings for different conventions: for example, it can be used to emphasize that formula_3 and formula_4 are <a href="Real%20number">real</a> vector spaces (not necessarily with formula_2), or it can be used to emphasize that formula_3 is a <a href="function%20space">function space</a>, which is a common convention in <a href="functional%20analysis">functional analysis</a>. Sometimes the term "<a href="linear%20function">linear function</a>" has the same meaning as "linear map", while in <a href="mathematical%20analysis">analysis</a> it does not.
A linear map from "V" to "W" always maps the origin of "V" to the origin of "W". Moreover, it maps <a href="linear%20subspace">linear subspace</a>s in "V" onto linear subspaces in "W" (possibly of a lower <a href="Dimension%20%28vector%20space%29">dimension</a>); for example, it maps a <a href="Plane%20%28geometry%29">plane</a> through the <a href="Origin%20%28geometry%29">origin</a> in "V" to either a plane through the origin in "W", a <a href="Line%20%28geometry%29">line</a> through the origin in "W", or just the origin in "W". Linear maps can often be represented as <a href="matrix%20%28mathematics%29">matrices</a>, and simple examples include <a href="Rotations%20and%20reflections%20in%20two%20dimensions">rotation and reflection linear transformations</a>.
In the language of <a href="category%20theory">category theory</a>, linear maps are the <a href="morphism">morphism</a>s of vector spaces.

Vector space of linear maps.
The composition of linear maps is linear: if formula_10 and formula_136 are linear, then so is their <a href="Relation%20composition">composition</a> formula_137. It follows from this that the <a href="class%20%28set%20theory%29">class</a> of all vector spaces over a given field "K", together with "K"-linear maps as <a href="morphism">morphism</a>s, forms a <a href="category%20%28mathematics%29">category</a>.
The <a href="inverse%20function">inverse</a> of a linear map, when defined, is again a linear map.
If formula_138 and formula_139 are linear, then so is their <a href="pointwise">pointwise</a> sum formula_140, which is defined by formula_141.

Thus the set formula_147 of linear maps from formula_148 to formula_149 itself forms a vector space over formula_144, sometimes denoted formula_151. Furthermore, in the case that formula_152, this vector space, denoted formula_153, is an <a href="associative%20algebra">associative algebra</a> under <a href="composition%20of%20maps">composition of maps</a>, since the composition of two linear maps is again a linear map, and the composition of maps is always associative. This case is discussed in more detail below.
Given again the finite-dimensional case, if bases have been chosen, then the composition of linear maps corresponds to the <a href="matrix%20multiplication">matrix multiplication</a>, the addition of linear maps corresponds to the <a href="matrix%20addition">matrix addition</a>, and the multiplication of linear maps with scalars corresponds to the multiplication of matrices with scalars.
Endomorphisms and automorphisms.
A linear transformation formula_154 is an <a href="endomorphism">endomorphism</a> of formula_148; the set of all such endomorphisms formula_156 together with addition, composition and scalar multiplication as defined above forms an <a href="associative%20algebra">associative algebra</a> with identity element over the field formula_144 (and in particular a <a href="ring%20%28algebra%29">ring</a>). The multiplicative identity element of this algebra is the <a href="identity%20function">identity map</a> formula_158.
An endomorphism of formula_148 that is also an <a href="isomorphism">isomorphism</a> is called an <a href="automorphism">automorphism</a> of formula_148. The composition of two automorphisms is again an automorphism, and the set of all automorphisms of formula_148 forms a <a href="group%20%28math%29">group</a>, the <a href="automorphism%20group">automorphism group</a> of formula_148 which is denoted by formula_163 or formula_164. Since the automorphisms are precisely those <a href="endomorphisms">endomorphisms</a> which possess inverses under composition, formula_163 is the group of <a href="Unit%20%28ring%20theory%29">units</a> in the ring formula_156.
If formula_148 has finite dimension formula_168, then formula_153 is <a href="isomorphism">isomorphic</a> to the <a href="associative%20algebra">associative algebra</a> of all formula_170 matrices with entries in formula_144. The automorphism group of formula_148 is <a href="group%20isomorphism">isomorphic</a> to the <a href="general%20linear%20group">general linear group</a> formula_173 of all formula_170 invertible matrices with entries in formula_144.

Cokernel.
A subtler invariant of a linear transformation formula_52 is the <a href="cokernel">"co"kernel</a>, which is defined as

This is the "dual" notion to the kernel: just as the kernel is a "sub"space of the "domain," the co-kernel is a <a href="quotient%20space%20%28linear%20algebra%29">"quotient" space</a> of the "target." Formally, one has the <a href="exact%20sequence">exact sequence</a>
formula_200
These can be interpreted thus: given a linear equation "f"(v) = w to solve,
The dimension of the co-kernel and the dimension of the image (the rank) add up to the dimension of the target space. For finite dimensions, this means that the dimension of the quotient space "W"/"f"("V") is the dimension of the target space minus the dimension of the image.
As a simple example, consider the map "f": R2 → R2, given by "f"("x", "y") = (0, "y"). Then for an equation "f"("x", "y") = ("a", "b") to have a solution, we must have "a" = 0 (one constraint), and in that case the solution space is ("x", "b") or equivalently stated, (0, "b") + ("x", 0), (one degree of freedom). The kernel may be expressed as the subspace ("x", 0) < "V": the value of "x" is the freedom in a solution – while the cokernel may be expressed via the map "W" → R, formula_201: given a vector ("a", "b"), the value of "a" is the "obstruction" to there being a solution.
An example illustrating the infinite-dimensional case is afforded by the map "f": R∞ → R∞, formula_202 with "b"1 = 0 and "b""n" + 1 = "an" for "n" > 0. Its image consists of all sequences with first element 0, and thus its cokernel consists of the classes of sequences with identical first element. Thus, whereas its kernel has dimension 0 (it maps only the zero sequence to the zero sequence), its co-kernel has dimension 1. Since the domain and the target space are the same, the rank and the dimension of the kernel add up to the same <a href="cardinal%20number%23Cardinal%20addition">sum</a> as the rank and the dimension of the co-kernel (formula_203), but in the infinite-dimensional case it cannot be inferred that the kernel and the co-kernel of an <a href="endomorphism">endomorphism</a> have the same dimension (0 ≠ 1). The reverse situation obtains for the map "h": R∞ → R∞, formula_204 with "cn" = "a""n" + 1. Its image is the entire target space, and hence its co-kernel has dimension 0, but since it maps all sequences in which only the first element is non-zero to the zero sequence, its kernel has dimension 1.
Index.
For a linear operator with finite-dimensional kernel and co-kernel, one may define "index" as:
formula_205
namely the degrees of freedom minus the number of constraints.
For a transformation between finite-dimensional vector spaces, this is just the difference dim("V") − dim("W"), by rank–nullity. This gives an indication of how many solutions or how many constraints one has: if mapping from a larger space to a smaller one, the map may be onto, and thus will have degrees of freedom even without constraints. Conversely, if mapping from a smaller space to a larger one, the map cannot be onto, and thus one will have constraints even without degrees of freedom.
The index of an operator is precisely the <a href="Euler%20characteristic">Euler characteristic</a> of the 2-term complex 0 → "V" → "W" → 0. In <a href="operator%20theory">operator theory</a>, the index of <a href="Fredholm%20operator">Fredholm operator</a>s is an object of study, with a major result being the <a href="Atiyah%E2%80%93Singer%20index%20theorem">Atiyah–Singer index theorem</a>.

Continuity.
A "linear transformation" between <a href="topological%20vector%20space">topological vector space</a>s, for example <a href="normed%20space">normed space</a>s, may be <a href="continuous%20function%20%28topology%29">continuous</a>. If its domain and codomain are the same, it will then be a <a href="continuous%20linear%20operator">continuous linear operator</a>. A linear operator on a normed linear space is continuous if and only if it is <a href="bounded%20operator">bounded</a>, for example, when the domain is finite-dimensional. An infinite-dimensional domain may have <a href="discontinuous%20linear%20operator">discontinuous linear operator</a>s.
An example of an unbounded, hence discontinuous, linear transformation is differentiation on the space of smooth functions equipped with the supremum norm (a function with small values can have a derivative with large values, while the derivative of 0 is 0). For a specific example, converges to 0, but its derivative does not, so differentiation is not continuous at 0 (and by a variation of this argument, it is not continuous anywhere).
Applications.
A specific application of linear maps is for <a href="geometric%20transformation">geometric transformation</a>s, such as those performed in <a href="computer%20graphics">computer graphics</a>, where the translation, rotation and scaling of 2D or 3D objects is performed by the use of a <a href="transformation%20matrix">transformation matrix</a>. Linear mappings also are used as a mechanism for describing change: for example in calculus correspond to derivatives; or in relativity, used as a device to keep track of the local transformations of reference frames.
Another application of these transformations is in <a href="compiler%20optimizations">compiler optimizations</a> of nested-loop code, and in <a href="parallelizing%20compiler">parallelizing compiler</a> techniques.
